sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Gonorrhea: 800 mg ORALLY as a single dose
  • Prostatitis: 400 mg ORALLY every 12 hr for 28 days
  • Traveler's diarrhea: 400 mg ORALLY twice daily for 1 to 3 days
  • Urinary tract infectious disease: uncomplicated infection: 400 mg ORALLY every 12 hr; administer for 3 days for E. coli, K. pneumoniae or P. mirabilis infections; administer for 7 to 10 days for infections due to other organisms
  • Urinary tract infectious disease: complicated infection: 400 mg ORALLY every 12 hr for 10 to 21 days

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: Safety and efficacy in children under 18 years of age have not been established

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: renal impairment: CrCl 30 mL/min or less, 400 mg once a day

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Bacterial conjunctivitis
  • Gonorrhea
  • Prostatitis
  • Urinary tract infectious disease
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Cholera
  • Immunodeficiency disorder - Infectious disease; Prophylaxis
  • Malaria
  • Salmonella infection
  • Traveler's diarrhea
  • Traveler's diarrhea; Prophylaxis
  • Urinary tract infectious disease; Prophylaxis

mono.title: Black Box Warning
mono.mono:
Oral (Tablet)
Fluoroquinolones, including norfloxacin, are associated with an increased risk of tendinitis and tendon rupture in all ages. Risk further increases with age over 60 years, concomitant steroid therapy, and kidney, heart, or lung transplants. Fluoroquinolones, including norfloxacin, may exacerbate muscle weakness in persons with myasthenia gravis. Avoid in patients with known history of myasthenia gravis.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to norfloxacin or other quinolones
  • tendinitis or tendon rupture associated with norfloxacin or other quinolones, history of

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• myasthenia gravis; may exacerbate muscle weakness; ventilatory support requirement and death have been reported; avoid use
  • tendinitis and tendon rupture, increased risk; risk further increases with age over 60 years, concomitant steroid therapy, and kidney, heart or lung transplant; discontinue therapy at first sign of tendon pain, swelling or inflammation
  • anaphylactic reactions; fatal hypersensitivities, some following first dose, have occurred
  • central nervous system disorders such as severe cerebral arteriosclerosis, epilepsy, and other factors predisposing patient to seizures
  • coadministration with Class IA (eg, procainamide, quinidine) or Class III (eg, amiodarone, sotalol) antiarrhythmic agents
  • elderly patients; increased risk of toxicity due to decreased renal function
  • excessive sunlight exposure; risk for phototoxic reactions
  • glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase activity defects, latent or actual; increased risk of hemolytic reactions
  • hypokalemia; increased risk of QTc prolongation
  • impaired renal function; increased risk of toxicity and tendon rupture; dosage adjustment recommended
  • pediatric patients; safety and efficacy not established
  • peripheral neuropathy has been reported with oral and injectable fluoroquinolones; may occur any time during therapy and persist for months to years or become permanent even after discontinuation; if symptoms occur, discontinue use and switch to a non-fluoroquinolone unless benefit outweighs risk
  • physical activity, strenuous; may increase risk of tendon rupture
  • pregnancy, nursing mothers; safety and efficacy not established
  • proarrhythmic conditions (eg, significant bradycardia or acute myocardial ischemia); increased risk of QTc prolongation
  • tendon disorders, such as rheumatoid arthritis, history of; may increase risk of tendon rupture

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

mono.title: Adverse Effects
mono.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea (2.6% to 4.2%), Stomach cramps (2.6%)
  • Neurologic:Dizziness (1.7% to 2.6%), Headache (2% to 2.8%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Prolonged QT interval, Vasculitis
  • Dermatologic:Stevens-Johnson syndrome, Toxic epidermal necrolysis
  • Gastrointestinal:Clostridium difficile diarrhea
  • Hematologic:Anemia, Aplastic anemia, Thrombocytopenia
  • Hepatic:Hepatitis, Jaundice, Liver failure
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction (Severe)
  • Musculoskeletal:Myasthenia gravis, Exacerbation, Rupture of tendon, Tendinitis
  • Neurologic:Peripheral neuropathy, Seizure
  • Ophthalmic:Retinal detachment
  • Renal:Interstitial nephritis
  • Other:Fever

mono.title: Mechanism Of Action
mono.mono: Ophthalmic: Norfloxacin is bactericidal and acts by inhibiting bacterial deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) synthesis. Norfloxacin is a broad-spectrum anti-infective, active against a wide range of aerobic gram-positive and gram-negative organisms. The fluorine atom at the 6 position increases potency against gram-negative organisms, and the piperazine moiety at the 7 position is responsible for anti-pseudomonal activity.

mono.title: Administration
mono.mono:
Oral
  • take at least 1 hour before or 2 hour after food or dairy products
  • if given together, multivitamins with iron should not be taken within 2 hour before or 2 hour after the dose
  • if given together, multivitamins with zinc should not be taken within 2 hour before or 2 hour after the dose
  • if given together, antacids containing aluminum or magnesium should not be taken within 2 hour before or 2 hour after the dose
  • if given together, sucralfate should not be taken within 2 hour before or 2 hour after the dose
  • if given together, didanosine buffered tablets or powder for oral solution should not be taken within 2 hour or 2 hour after the dose

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
FLUOROQUINOLONES
USES: Fluoroquinolones are bacteriocidal broad spectrum antibiotics. PHARMACOLOGY: Fluoroquinolones inhibit bacterial topoisomerase IV and DNA gyrase enzymes required for DNA replication, transcription, repair and recombination. EPIDEMIOLOGY: Overdose is rare. OVERDOSE: Dizziness, drowsiness, disorientation, slurred speech, nausea and vomiting. ADVERSE EFFECTS: Nausea/vomiting, diarrhea, headache, drowsiness, and insomnia. Seizures, hallucinations, elevated liver enzymes and renal toxicity are rare. Seizures appear related to predisposing factors. Hypersensitivity reactions including anaphylaxis and vasculitis have developed. WITHDRAWAL FROM MARKET: Grepafloxacin was withdrawn from the worldwide market in October, 1999 after reports of cardiovascular toxicity; QT prolongation had been associated with its use. Gatifloxacin was voluntarily withdrawn from the market in May 2006 due to reports of severe hypo- and hyperglycemic events.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
FLUOROQUINOLONES
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
  • Decontamination: Activated charcoal, gastric lavage
  • Seizure: IV benzodiazepines, barbiturates
  • Monitoring of patient: Monitor liver enzymes and renal function with significant overdose. Monitor fluid & electrolyte status if severe GI effects; CNS function.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
FLUOROQUINOLONES
Unknown. Recommended dose (adults): 300-500 mg BID; contraindicated in children.

mono.title: Clinical Teaching
mono.mono:
• Instruct patient to immediately report symptoms of tendonitis or tendon rupture (pain, swelling, inflammation of tendon), especially if elderly and/or using concomitant steroids.
  • Tell patient to immediately report symptoms of peripheral neuropathy, including pain, burning, tingling, or numbness.
  • Advise patient to use sunscreen, avoid tanning beds, and avoid excessive exposure to sunlight as drug causes phototoxicity.
  • Counsel patient to avoid activities requiring coordination until drug effects are realized, as drug may cause dizziness and lightheadedness.
  • Side effects may include nausea, abdominal cramping, or headaches.
  • Instruct patient to immediately report severe diarrhea, dermatologic reactions (toxic epidermal necrolysis, Stevens-Johnson), or QT prolongation (palpitations, loss of consciousness).
  • Advise patient to immediately report CNS events (hallucinations, depression, suicidal thoughts, or convulsions).
  • Counsel patient to take drug at least 1 hour before or 2 hours after a meal or dairy products (milk, yogurt).
  • Advise patient to take drug 2 hours before or after magnesium or aluminum-containing antacids or products containing calcium, iron, or zinc.
  • Tell patient to maintain adequate hydration.
  • Advise patient to avoid caffeine during therapy due to enhanced caffeine effects.
